page.title: 02Belstone Common -2
page.content: The tumbled ruins of a wall known as Irishman's Wall bisect Belstone Tor. The story goes that an Irishman who wished to enclose part of the moor employed some of his countrymen to build a considerable length of wall. The locals watched the wall develop and after a large portion had been built, ganged together and destroyed it. After that the Irishman gave up and left the area. Watchet Hill on the border of this block and the one to the north has old stonecutters' tracks leading to Belstone. Belstone granite was used a hundred years ago for building gateposts and other agricultural purposes. The stone was roughly cut on the moor and then transferred to Belstone for finishing.
